messageBody:
Since other people's view was explicitely requested, here comes mine...

BTW, your posting style makes it very hard for me to see what's a quote and
what's your comment. But maybe that's just my configuration of yahoogroups. I
have been trying to sort it out by adding another '>' in lines I suppose you
quoted.

>> Your underlying hypothesis appears to be this:
>>
>> If class A depends on B, then there exist tests T(A) that test A and
>> tests T(B) that test B such that T(A) depends on T(B).
>
> Actaully, no (although it isn't something I object to for many use cases).
>
> I am merely asking that I can assert that T(A) depends on T(B) [for
> whatever reason] and I do so in T(A) [somehow] not in some separate
suite(A).

This seems to me to be the crucial point. IF you don't have side effects and
IF you have decoupled code then I cannot see where dependencies between T(A)
and T(B) make sense. A usually does not depend directly on B but on an
abstract interface - B just being an implementation of that interface.

>> Get this straight: TEST CASE DEPENDENCY IS EVIL. Test cases should be as
>> independent as possible. It should be possible to select a number of
tests
>> and just run them. JUnit supports that. You can build your TestSuite
>> however you want. The fact that there aren't better tools for this
surprises me.
>
> No, here .... you are wrong. I beleive you mean that test cases ought have
> no "results" or "side effects" that other test cases depended upon. That
> is EVIL!!! Agreed, 100%.
>
> Run order (call it dependency order or whatever) that is not evil. If my
> collection object fails, why run the test of things that use it & waste
time
> debugging their failures? Even if by chance they worked, so what, trim
> down the results a human has to think over.

Maybe the direct dependency on the collection object is the problem in the
first place. You could take your problem with many test cases failing at once
as a strong hint to remove this direct dependency. If your collection object,
however, is so low level that a direct dependency does not hurt then it
should be very very stable; the probability that it fails in a fundamental way,
which makes lots of other tests fail too, is very low.

>> Well, in general, JUnit doesn't change much. That's intentional. That's
>> why we have projects like JUnit-addons, GSBase and so on.
>
> I agree with the goal, but some things are worth change. Although I've
> followed your arguments (and support them) about keeping frameworks
> simple/pure & add-ons outside, (respectfully) I don't beleive you are
fully opening
> you mind to that option. Lack of change is not an argument in itself.
> Sometimes the further you are from something the easier it is to see
something,
> and I feel you are too close to junit and the goal of keeping it simple to
> see this does not break that. Thaa said, maybe I've just failed to explain
> it. Want me to start again?
>
> Perhaps others have a point of view, I really do think a lot of this comes
> down to user choice and use cases.

You haven't convinced me (yet) about two points:
- Why is the dependency between tests a FUNDAMENTAL concept and not just
your very personal way to sort out which test cases to run?
- Why can't this concept be implemented without changing the core of JUnit?

But of course you're right stati8ng that many of us here are too involved in
JUnit and thus have a hard time giving up on "invariants" we consider to be
"everlasting".

Johannes
